required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacokinetic Study Comparing Tiotropium Easyhaler® and Spiriva® HandiHaler®
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Tiotropium Pharmacokinetics After Inhalation From Tiotropium Easyhaler® Product Variants and After Spiriva® Capsules Administered Via HandiHaler®; Study in Healthy Volunteers

brief_summary.textblock: Absorption of inhaled tiotropium is compared between five Tiotropium Easyhaler product variants and Spiriva capsules inhaled via HandiHaler without charcoal. Absorption of tiotropium is compared between one Easyhaler product variant administered with and without charcoal.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The study is a 2-part 4-period crossover study where the study subjects participate either in part 1 (20 subjects) or in part 2 (20 subjects). Parts can run in sequence or parallel. All study subjects receive single dose of Tiotropium Easyhaler on 3 periods and Spiriva HandiHaler on 1 period.
study_design_info.masking_description: Bioanalytical laboratory will be blinded with regard to the sequence of the product administration.

primary_outcome.measure: Area under the concentration-time curve from time zero to 30 minutes (AUC30 minutes)
Area under the concentration-time curve from time zero to 72 hours (AUC72 hours)

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to reach peak concentration in plasma (tmax)

other_outcome.time_frame: througout the study, an average 9 weeks

arm_group.arm_group_label: Tiotropium Easyhaler Product variant F administered with oral activated charcoal

intervention.arm_group_label: Tiotropium Easyhaler Product variant F administered with oral activated charcoal

criteria.textblock:
Main inclusion criteria:
1. Healthy males and females
2. 18-60 years of age
3. Body mass index 19-30 kg/m2
4. Weight at least 50 kg
5. Written informed consent obtained
Main exclusion criteria:
1. Evidence of a clinically significant cardiovascular, renal, hepatic, haematological, gastrointestinal, pulmonary, metabolic, endocrine, neurological or psychiatric disease
2. Any condition requiring regular concomitant treatment
3. Any clinically significant abnormal laboratory value or physical finding that in the opinion of the investigator could interfere with the interpretation of study results or cause a health risk for the subject
4. Known hypersensitivity to tiotropium bromide, atropine or its derivatives or lactose
5. Pregnant or lactating females and females of childbearing potential not using contraception of acceptable effectiveness
6. Blood donation or loss of significant amount of blood within 90 days prior to the first study treatment administration.
